title: CTS Corp (CTS) Q1 2019 Earnings Call Transcript
callText:
Image source: The Motley Fool.

CTS Corp  (NYSE:CTS)Q1 2019 Earnings CallApril 25, 2019, 11:00 a.m. ET
Contents:

Prepared Remarks
Questions and Answers
Call Participants



Trending

Guess Who Just Became Amazon's Biggest Shipper
3 Hot Growth Stocks I'd Buy Right Now
3 Reasons People Don't Use Annuities the Way They Were Meant to Be Used


Prepared Remarks:
Operator
Good day, and welcome to the CTS Corporation First Quarter Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Kieran O'Sullivan. Please go ahead, sir.
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Great. Thank you, Jessica. Good morning. Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to CTS' First Quarter 2019 Conference Call.
Sales in the first quarter were $117.6 million, up 3.6% versus the same period in 2018. We added four new customers in the quarter. First quarter adjusted gross margins of 34.5%, improved 60 basis points compared to 33.9% in the same period last year. First quarter adjusted earnings per share were $0.39 compared to $0.34 in the first quarter of 2018. We ended the quarter with total booked business of $1.87 billion.
Ashish Agrawal is with me for today's call and will take us through the Safe Harbor statement. Ashish?
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
I would like to remind our listeners that this conference call contains forward looking statements. These statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in the forward-looking statements. Additional information regarding these risks and uncertainties is contained in the press release issued today and more information can be found in the Company's SEC filings.
To the extent that today's discussion refers to any non-GAAP measures under Regulation G, the required explanations and reconciliations are available in the Investors section of the CTS website.
I will now turn the discussion back over to our CEO, Kieran O'Sullivan.
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Ashish. In the first quarter of 2019, our sales growth was 3.6%. We added four new customers in the quarter. Total booked business was $1.87 billion, flat to the end of last year. This was driven by the timing of some customers' sourcing decisions, which we expect to balance out in the months ahead. The year began with softness in the Chinese market, industrial markets and distributors focused on reducing inventories. We continue to see solid performance in medical and defense markets.
Our overall 6.1% growth in transportation was primarily driven by gains in our Brushless DC motor product line. Currency rates unfavorably impacted sales by $1.8 million, mostly in the transportation end market. We are carefully managing operating expenses, monitoring our capital spending and prioritizing investments as we maintain our focus on results and continue to drive profitable growth. We continue to expand our range of sensing, connectivity and motion products. Recently, we developed an inductive accelerator module and secured our first OEM award in the first quarter. This product will be an important addition for growth with electric vehicles.
Our piezoceramic sensing technology was successfully qualified for an application in fingerprint security last year, and we expect further progress in the second half of 2019. We believe that sensors are the fundamental building blocks that enable the safer, cleaner and more efficient world. We are also innovating with new wireless switch applications for vehicles and eBrake solutions to complement ADAS systems. Consumers and companies demand universal and seamless data connectivity. Our family of RF filters, ClearPlex and Monoblock products gained considerable traction with several new connectivity customers for deployment in massive MIMO and small cell systems. The filters are located in antenna arrays, enabling faster data connectivity.
We are excited about the arrival of 5G systems, as it will create opportunities for us with applications, technology and devices driving sales growth. We have more to do as we transition our Company for success beyond 2020.
In the first quarter, we secured several notable wins. As I mentioned, we continue to gain traction with our expanding RF filter portfolio and see interest and demand for prototypes for applications driven by our universal design and ClearPlex platform and expect revenues will continue to increase in 2019.
In transportation, we secured several new accelerator module awards including the one I mentioned earlier for our inductive pedal design with a North American OEM, a new EV customer in China and another win for an OEM serve in the Eastern European market with a lifetime value of $20 million. We also had sensor wins in the quarter in the China market for new SUV programs. We were awarded two new programs for defense applications with annual revenues of $2 million and we secured our first order for RF filters for an application in aerospace connectivity.
Last year, we launched our Throttle Sensing Module in the Chinese and Indian, two wheeler markets. We are now ramping up production and expect sales growth of about $3 million for 2019.
Overall, we continue to target a combined sales growth rate of 10%, 5% organic and 5% through strategic acquisitions. Making further progress on our end market profile is a strategic priority for us. We continue to evaluate our portfolio of products and technologies and strengthen our M&A pipeline.
We remain focused on adding the right technologies, expanding our geographic reach and strengthening our product portfolio and customer relationships. The consolidation of manufacturing from Elkhart, Indiana to other sites and from Bolingbrook to Lisle, Illinois have now been completed. We continue to evaluate and work on other consolidation opportunities. With the largest manufacturing consolidations completed over the past years, we will focus more on the prioritization of R&D projects and engineering effectiveness as we grow our best cost capabilities.
Our ERP rollout continues and will position us to gain further efficiencies beyond 2020 in various aspects of our supply chain. End markets were challenging as we began the year with global trade challenges and slower growth in China. Passenger vehicle volumes have declined by single digits as we near the end of an expansion cycle. Our performance remain steady. We saw lower bookings in industrial and distribution markets in the fourth quarter and this impacted revenues in the first quarter.
Medical and defense markets remain robust, where we continue to see solid growth. Profitable growth, margin improvement, ERP implementation and end market profile progress, are priorities for us this year.
For full year 2019, we are maintaining our guidance and expect sales to be in the range of $460 million to $500 million and adjusted earnings in the range of a $1.50 to $1.70.
At this time, Ashish will walk us through the financial performance. Ashish?
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
Thank you, Kieran. First quarter sales were $117.6 million, up 3.6% compared to the prior year. Sales to transportation customers increased by 6.1% and sales to other end markets decreased by 1.1%, due to softness in the industrial and distribution markets.
Our gross margin was 34.5% in the first quarter versus 33.9% in the first quarter of 2018. During the first quarter 2019, we realized approximately $1.5 million in savings related to manufacturing transition, partially offset by material cost increases and Mexico wage increases. We expect full year savings from the manufacturing transfers to be in the range of $3 million to $4 million.
SG&A and R&D expenses were $24.3 million or 20.7% of sales compared to 21% in the first quarter last year. Our effective income tax rate in the first quarter of 2019 was 20%, down from 24.5% last year, mainly due to the discrete tax benefit related to equity-based compensation.
We expect our full year tax rate to be in the range of 23% to 25% excluding discrete items. Our first quarter 2019 earnings were $0.34 per diluted share. Adjusted earnings per diluted share were $0.39, up $0.05 compared to the first quarter of last year.
Now I'll discuss some items on the balance sheet and cash flow. Our controllable working capital as a percentage of sales was 15.3% in the first quarter. We started working down our safety stock related to the transfer of production from Elkhart to other locations. We have more work to do to improve working capital efficiency in the coming quarters. We generated $9.6 million in operating cash flow in the first quarter.
CapEx was $5.3 million, consistent with our prior communication, we expect our 2019 CapEx to be in the range of 6% to 8% of sales with a return to more normal levels in 2020.
Cash was $100.7 million on March 31, 2019 compared to $100.9 million at the end of 2018. Our long-term debt balance was $50 million at the end of March, flat with December 2018.
Our debt to capitalization ratio was at 11.4% compared to 11.7% at the end of 2018. During the first quarter, we repurchased 31,500 shares of our stock for $849,000. We have $24.7 million remaining under the repurchase plan approved in February.
During the first quarter, we also completed the renewal of our $300 million credit facility and extended the maturity of the facility to February 2024. The SAP implementation project is progressing, we have so far completed the rollout of SAP to six manufacturing sites and two shared service locations. We are carefully managing the rollout to minimize the impact on our customers and are expecting to complete the project in the first half of 2020.
This concludes our prepared comments. We would like to open the line for questions at this time.



Related Articles



CTS Corp (CTS) Q4 2018 Earnings Conference Call Transcript


3 Stocks Near 52-Week Highs Worth Selling


CTS Beats on EPS But GAAP Results Lag


Questions and Answers:
Operator
Thank you. (Operator Instructions) We'll go first to John Franzreb with Sidoti & Company.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Hi. It's John Franzreb. Good morning, Ashish and Kieran.
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Good morning, John.
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
Hi, John.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Okay. Just to make sure you heard me there. Couple of questions, first to Kieran. How would you assess the operating environment today compared to three months ago, you've been voicing caution on the transportation market with quite sometime. Has that outlook changed at all?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
John, we were coming into this year saying we expect to see low single digits in the transportation market, you can see that the performance across the industry was probably in quarter one negative 5% to 6%. And if you take out our Brushless motor which we called out in the earnings transcript, and you take it the FX adjustment, we were essentially flat when the market was down in transportation for 5.6% (ph). So pretty much in line with where we expect it to be. And obviously, we saw softness at the end of the year, coming into Q1 in industrial and China and that impacted sales in Q1 and we're seeing signs of stabilization there. So hopefully that gives you some color.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Yes. Because I wanted to ask about the Brushless DC motor sales. Can you remind us what they go into and why they were so strong in the first quarter?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Yeah. They go into commercial vehicles and some into trucks as well, in the light vehicle market. And we're seeing as good share gains there and good momentum in that market. So we're performing well.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
So would you expect those sales to continue to outperform into Q2 and help offset the weakness you're seeing in other products in the transportation lines?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Yeah. When we look at that market John, we probably see just -- first of all, we expect a good performance there. We would -- in the next few quarters, end of the year, we might see some softness toward the very end of the year. If you look at it what we're seeing is Europe is OK, North America strong and China has had some softness. But overall, a good trend for the next few quarters maybe, you get to (ph) see some softness toward the end of the year.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Okay. Fair enough. Regarding the transition and the restructuring that you're undertaking, Ashish has mentioned that there's opportunity here to improve your working capital profile. When do you think that you'll be beyond maybe growing (ph) extra inventory or the things like that you'd be pass those kind of hurdles?
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
John, as I mentioned in the script, we have already started working through our safety stock. My expectation is in the early part of second half of the year, we should be able to completely deplete our safety stock.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Early part of the second. Got it. All right. And one last question, Kieran, you mentioned the target is 10%. I mean, you've kind of alluded to the fact, you're growing organically in the low single digits, which brings us to the delta there between that and the 10% is M&A. What is the M&A environment look like right now? And you kind of fill us in well -- on that side of the coin?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Nothing significant to report John, all I would say is that, we've been working much harder on our pipeline and -- at building strength in that area. But obviously, our strategy hasn't changed for the assets that we're looking for in line with what we've communicated in the past.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Okay. All right. Thanks, guys. I'll get back into queue.
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, John.
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
Thanks, John.
Operator
(Operator Instructions) We'll go to Hendi Susanto with G. Research.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Good morning. Kieran and Ashish.
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
Hi, Hendi.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
My first question is similar to John's first question. Can you share more color on your cautious view, this time is on the industrial side, what has changed since three months ago and what areas are below and above your prior expectations?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Yeah. We -- first of all, I think we saw the softness in China. That's probably been the biggest thing we've seen. And there's some trade things going on there in the middle of that, but mostly it's the softness in the market. And then one or two customers that have basically got a softer end market because of that and that's really some of the drivers.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
I see. So Kieran, let's say if the US China trade discussion got resolved. How quickly do you think the market in industrial will improve? Do you think it can improve quickly relatively or do you think it may take some time?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
I think it can improve in a quarter or so. And the other thing, Hendi, I should mention is to the first part of your question as well, we saw some inventories building up in distribution, and they usually take somewhere between a quarter or two to correct. So that's the other part of the equation just impacting it overall.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
And then the inventory build -- like happen in both industrial and some transportation, I assume?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Sorry. Can you say that again Hendi?
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
The inventory builds that you mentioned, did it happen in both the industrial and transportation or did you talk specifically about inventory build in industrials?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Yeah, industrial and in distribution primarily. When I look at the order side of it, there's been in transportation. There's been a small increase in days on hand, but it's kind of a mixed thing up, nothing I'd call, I had to say we've got a big issue there.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
I see. And then Kieran you also mentioned the finger sensing application. So what should be our expectation going forward?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
I would say Hendi, we're making progress through the development and qualification as we've highlighted, that takes time to get traction. But we should be giving you a more clearer update on that in the second half of this year.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Yeah. And then will you be able to share what type of function of your finger sensing application, like how different it is versus what is being offered at the market now?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Yeah. I mean -- what you're seeing in the market is a combination of facial and fingerprint -- they were separate, now they are combined. So you see the need for that extra security with the fingerprint. And I think you'll see that trend going forward in devices.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Okay. So let's say, I think we know that the facial and fingerprint now it's already combined. So what really of being -- what kind of new features that your finger sensing application will bring into the table.
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
When you look at it, I think with our technologies that we have, you can get more of a 3D versus the 2D security application getting below the fingerprint into the vessels and into the bones, so you get a much and more secure application.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Okay. So it can penetrate deeper into your fingerprint essentially?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Correct.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
I see. Yeah. And then, Ashish, a question about restructuring charge. How much restructuring charge should we expect for the remainder of the year?
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
Hendi, the bulk of the work is completed in Elkhart.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Yeah.
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
So going forward, I'm expecting smaller amounts as we go through the final cleanup and other things. There might be some non-cash impairment type of things that we might encounter as we go through the final stages, but nothing significant, which will require considerable cash outflow at this point.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Yeah. And then Kieran, do you have insight into your telecom and IT markets?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Yeah. We've been really focused on the RF filters in that space, where we're shipping some products and qualify with others. And in the prepared comments I said that we would continue to see growth in that area. And then as we look at that space even going forward, we're kind of excited about the 5G opportunities out there for both RF filters and for our frequency products as well.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Okay, got it. Thank you, Kieran. Thank you, Ashish.
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
You're welcome, Hendi.
Operator
(Operator Instructions) We'll now take a question from John Franzreb with Sidoti & Company.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Yeah. I guess just regarding the timing of orders that you talked about that your incoming booking was kind of flat at $1.87 billion. How much was deferred by the decision-making process and how much maybe was it just a soft kind of a customer order book for the quarter relative to your expectations?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Yeah. More and more deferred John on the timing of decisions and the sourcing. So that's why in the comments,we said, it's something that we get balanced out here in the next few months. And sometimes these things happen in the quarter, we've seen it in the past. So nothing unusual here.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Okay. And regarding distribution, you cited a couple of times Kieran, I assume it's all non-transportation related for you. If that's not the case, clarify that? And how much is it of your say 2018 revenues and how big of a pie's (ph) distribution for you?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
So it's mostly non-automotive and it's in the single digits of sales overall.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Okay. But it still has a meaningful sway factor as far as the revenue profile for you? Is there any --
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Yeah. For our electronic -- sorry, go ahead, John.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
I was going to say is there any seasonality maybe we should be cognizant of when it comes to when distributors order on a normal buying pattern?
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
I would say we don't see a lot of seasonality, maybe a touch of it here and there. But also, I would just point out that we see signs of stabilization there. It takes time just when they build up inventory to burn it off. And I think they've been working through that.
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
John, there can be some pockets toward year-end, you might see a little bit of a slowdown and then around the Chinese New Year, there will be some slowdown in the Asian markets.
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Okay, guys. Thanks for the color. I appreciate it.
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Okay, John.
Operator
We will now take a question from Hendi Susanto with G. Research.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Ashish, if I look at the operating expense in Q1, it is higher on a year-over-year increase compared to the same period a year ago. Should we expect that OpEx level to be higher as we go through the remainder of the 2019 compared to 2018 I mean?
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
Hang on one moment, Hendi, I think what you're seeing is a increase in restructuring charges, excluding that the increase in OpEx is pretty nominal.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Okay.
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
And R&D has gone up slightly about a couple of $100,000 and SG&A is up $150,000-ish (ph). So not a significant cost increase. I expect us to continue looking at R&D strategically as we invest money in new product introductions and program launches that are already under way.
And on the SG&A side, as Kieran alluded, we are not expecting any significant improvements from the ERP implementation for at least beyond 2020. So our focus right now is to keep managing operating expenses prudently and keep a close eye on how the markets are performing as well.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
So in terms of where we should see the benefit of the recent restructuring charges among OpEx and COGS. Can you help us to think about those Ashish?
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
The restructuring charges are related to the Elkhart transition program that we started a couple of years ago and that's getting completed as we speak now.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Okay. And (multiple speakers)
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
And the benefits of that we had talked about savings of $6 million to $8 million on an annualized basis. And last year, we were able to get slightly more than $4 million. And we are guiding to $3 million to $4 million for this year.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
$3 million to $4 million for this year?
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
Right. And we had $1.5 million in Q1. Most of the savings -- the largest portion of the savings is in the gross margin numbers.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Okay. And then...
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
And Hendi just keep in mind that as we mentioned already, we have -- on the margin side a little bit of pressure with the wage changes in Mexico and so commodity pricing, so there's a little bit of balancing on the savings there.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Okay. So I'd say the labor increase (ph) in Mexico like partially offset the benefit in COGS?
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
That is correct.
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
Okay. Got it. Okay. Thank you, Ashish. Thank you, Kieran.
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
You're welcome.
Operator
I show no additional questions. I'd like to turn the call back to Kieran O'Sullivan for any additional or closing remarks.
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Okay. Thank you, Jessica, and thank you, everyone for joining the call today. We're back to focusing on execution here for the next quarter and for the balance of the year, and we look forward to updating you again in the July period. Thank you.
Operator
This concludes today's call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.
Duration: 28 minutes
Call participants:
Kieran O'Sullivan -- Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Ashish Agrawal -- Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
John Franzreb -- Sidoti & Company -- Analyst
Hendi Susanto -- G. Research -- Analyst
More CTS analysis
